statements.text: Apollo 11 was the first crewed mission to land humans on the Moon, launched by NASA in July 1969 on a Saturn V rocket from Kennedy Space Center.
The Apollo 11 crew consisted of commander Neil Armstrong, lunar module pilot Buzz Aldrin, and command module pilot Michael Collins.
After launch, Apollo 11 entered Earth orbit and then performed a translunar injection burn to set the spacecraft on course toward the Moon.
The command and service module Columbia remained in lunar orbit while the lunar module Eagle separated to carry Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin to the surface of the Moon.
On July 20, 1969, Eagle touched down on the Moon in the Sea of Tranquility and Armstrong reported to Houston, 'The Eagle has landed.'
When Neil Armstrong stepped off Eagle’s ladder onto the Moon, he described the moment as 'one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind.'
Buzz Aldrin soon joined Armstrong on the lunar surface, describing the Moon’s landscape as 'magnificent desolation.'
While his crewmates walked on the Moon, Michael Collins orbited alone in Columbia, maintaining systems and preparing for their return.
The astronauts deployed scientific experiments on the Moon, including a seismometer and laser retroreflector to study moonquakes and precisely measure the Earth–Moon distance.
The crew planted the United States flag in the lunar soil and left behind a plaque declaring that they came in peace for all mankind.
After about twenty-one hours on the lunar surface, Armstrong and Aldrin lifted off in Eagle’s ascent stage to rejoin Collins in lunar orbit.
Columbia performed a trans-Earth injection burn to leave lunar orbit and bring the Apollo 11 crew back toward Earth.
On July 24, 1969, Apollo 11 reentered Earth’s atmosphere and splashed down in the Pacific Ocean, where the crew was recovered by the aircraft carrier USS Hornet.
NASA placed the Apollo 11 astronauts in quarantine after splashdown to ensure that no harmful lunar microorganisms were brought back to Earth.
The success of Apollo 11 fulfilled President John F. Kennedy’s 1961 goal of landing a man on the Moon and returning him safely to Earth before the decade ended.
The Apollo 11 mission demonstrated the capabilities of the Saturn V rocket, advanced guidance computers, and worldwide tracking networks coordinated through Mission Control in Houston.
